attributes.action: Fairly manage the tax paid on fuel, by applying a 10p reduction or applying an upper limit, so as to soften the impact of fuel rises on the tax payer.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
I have to travel a large number of miles to get into work each day; the increased revenue the government is earning from fuel tax is exemplifying the rising fuel cost problem.  Working is not an option for me or millions of others in the country.  The only benefactors from the price rises are the treasury office and the multi billion dollar oil companies.

As David Smith points out in an article in the Sunday times,

"If prices stay close to present levels, the Treasury will be £6 billion better off this year."

Mr Smith then goes onto point out,
"As each 1p-a-litre cut in duty costs £500m, that windfall would allow a 12p per-litre cut. But let’s not be greedy: 10 is a number with topical resonance, so let’s have a 10p cut in petrol and diesel duty right now. Environmentalists shouldn’t complain because forecourt prices will still be up on last year, but we’ll all be happier..... ."
